title: Gas Evacuation Resumes In August
text:
16:38 CET Gas Evacuation Resumes In August By Daily Guide 
The Minister of Petroleum, Emmanuel Armah Kofi-Buah has stated that the evacuation of gas from the Jubilee Oilfield to the gas processing plant at Atuabo, which was disrupted as a result of the breakdown of the compressor on the FPSO Kwame Nkrumah, will resume in August, this year. 
The compressor on the FPSO broke down on July 3, this year, and this stopped gas evacuation from the Jubilee Oilfield to the processing plant to generate power. 
The Volta River Authority (VRA) was forced to use expensive light crude to ensure constant supply of power. 
Mr Kofi-Buah disclosed this when Dr George Sipa-Yankey, Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of Ghana Gas, a team from Tullow Ghana, as well as the Petroleum Commission visited the FPSO to ascertain the progress of work on the damaged compressor. 
'I have to say that we are encouraged by the hard work of the team on the FPSO. They are working day and night under extreme circumstances. They have made a lot of progress. They have mechanically completed the work on the compressor. 
'After the mechanical completion of work on the compressor, they will proceed with the testing of the system,' he added. 
Dr Sipa-Yankey said that the gas processing plant at Atuabo was ready to receive gas for onward transmission to VRA. 
'If tomorrow Tullow resumes export of gas, we are ready to receive gas and process for onward transmission to VRA,' Dr Yankey emphasized. 
He indicated that since the plant has to continue running for a stipulated number of hours, the engineers were running it. 
Charles Darko, CEO of Tullow Ghana, earlier indicated that production volumes had reduced from 110,0000 barrels per day to approximately 65,000 owing to the development. 
He emphasized that the reduction in production had affected the company's projections and 'that is why we are all working to ensure that we get back in line as quickly as possible.'
